node.title: What We Do
node.excerpt:
DSNP.org is an independent non-profit organization, focused on the Decentralized
Social Network Protocol (DSNP). The organization fits within the umbrella of 
Project Liberty [https://www.projectliberty.io/#/about] as the provider of one
core component (the social graph protocol) that connects the many different
technologies that make up a decentralized social network. Both DSNP.org and
Project Liberty have been launched out of Unfinished Labs
[https://www.unfinishedlabs.io/] as part of their ef
node.plaintext:
DSNP.org is an independent non-profit organization, focused on the Decentralized
Social Network Protocol (DSNP). The organization fits within the umbrella of 
Project Liberty [https://www.projectliberty.io/#/about] as the provider of one
core component (the social graph protocol) that connects the many different
technologies that make up a decentralized social network. Both DSNP.org and
Project Liberty have been launched out of Unfinished Labs
[https://www.unfinishedlabs.io/] as part of their efforts to build public
infrastructure for the web that puts citizens at the center of an innovative,
inclusive web economy.
node.html: DSNP.org is an independent non-profit organization, focused on the Decentralized Social Network Protocol (DSNP). The organization fits within the umbrella of Project Liberty as the provider of one core component (the social graph protocol) that connects the many different technologies that make up a decentralized social network. Both DSNP.org and Project Liberty have been launched out of Unfinished Labs as part of their efforts to build public infrastructure for the web that puts citizens at the center of an innovative, inclusive web economy.

node.title: Our Partners

node.plaintext:
Hi everyone! This is our first post in the DSNP.org Blog, and hopefully the
first of many more posts exploring the DSNP technology and solutions.

For decades private companies have controlled our social networks and related
data in walled gardens. They’ve controlled innovation. They’ve controlled how
value flows. This control starts with ownership of the social graph—the digital
representation of our online relationships that governs how we connect,
contribute, and consume. We believe the social graph should not be the property
of companies—it should belong to everyone. It should be basic public
infrastructure, like the core protocols that drive the web itself. We’ve
developed an open source, unified social graph that opens the path to reclaim
our networks. It’s called the Decentralized Social Networking Protocol (DSNP),
and it’s designed to transform the social graph from a corporate asset to
community-governed public infrastructure. Everything within this project is open
source.

If this is your first visit, the Decentralized Social Networking Protocol
(DSNP)
whitepaper
[https://github.com/LibertyDSNP/papers/blob/main/whitepaper/dsnp_whitepaper.pdf] 
is a good place to start. In our posts, we highlight some of the development
that has happened in the past month. We’ve included links to our repositories in
GitHub below.


April DSNP update — Summary of progress:
SDK

 * New packages published to NPM: In addition to the SDK package, our
   contributors have also added two new packages for test utilities, contract
   code, and ABIs. More information in this post
   [https://forums.projectliberty.io/t/two-more-npm-packages/34].
 * SDK documentation published on documentation website
   [https://libertydsnp.github.io/sdk-ts/].
 * Announce support added to SDK.

Spec

 * Tentative identity spec published
   [https://spec.projectliberty.io/Identity/Overview].
 * Decision made to use Parquet file format for batches.
 * Draft specification available [https://github.com/LibertyDSNP/spec/pull/34] 
   for: batch announce file format & batch announce filtering
 * Restyled spec website.
 * Code licenses updated to Apache 2.0.
 * Developer Portal [https://www.projectliberty.io/#/developer-portal] launched;
   incorporates new resources, including access to the SDK and spec.

Upcoming
 * Tentative specification for batch announce file format.
 * Tentative specification for batch announce filtering.
 * Registry contract written.
 * Identity logic contract written.
 * Beacon proxy and factory contracts written.
   

Join the discussion

The first and most important entry point of the project is our Discussion Forums
[https://forums.projectliberty.io/]. All questions and suggestions are welcome!
If you’re curious about something or just wondering where to start, please post
and we’ll do our best to help. You can also reach us by filing an issue in any
of our repositories [https://github.com/LibertyDSNP]. If you need to reach us
privately, please email hello@projectliberty.io.
node.html:
Hi everyone! This is our first post in the DSNP.org Blog, and hopefully the first of many more posts exploring the DSNP technology and solutions.

For decades private companies have controlled our social networks and related data in walled gardens. They’ve controlled innovation. They’ve controlled how value flows. This control starts with ownership of the social graph—the digital representation of our online relationships that governs how we connect, contribute, and consume. We believe the social graph should not be the property of companies—it should belong to everyone. It should be basic public infrastructure, like the core protocols that drive the web itself. We’ve developed an open source, unified social graph that opens the path to reclaim our networks. It’s called the Decentralized Social Networking Protocol (DSNP), and it’s designed to transform the social graph from a corporate asset to community-governed public infrastructure. Everything within this project is open source.

If this is your first visit, the Decentralized Social Networking Protocol (DSNP) whitepaper is a good place to start. In our posts, we highlight some of the development that has happened in the past month. We’ve included links to our repositories in GitHub below.

April DSNP update — Summary of progress:

SDK

  • New packages published to NPM: In addition to the SDK package, our contributors have also added two new packages for test utilities, contract code, and ABIs. More information in this post.
  • SDK documentation published on documentation website.
  • Announce support added to SDK.

Spec

  • Tentative identity spec published.
  • Decision made to use Parquet file format for batches.
  • Draft specification available for: batch announce file format & batch announce filtering
  • Restyled spec website.
  • Code licenses updated to Apache 2.0.
  • Developer Portal launched; incorporates new resources, including access to the SDK and spec.

Upcoming

  • Tentative specification for batch announce file format.
  • Tentative specification for batch announce filtering.
  • Registry contract written.
  • Identity logic contract written.
  • Beacon proxy and factory contracts written.

Join the discussion


The first and most important entry point of the project is our Discussion Forums. All questions and suggestions are welcome! If you’re curious about something or just wondering where to start, please post and we’ll do our best to help. You can also reach us by filing an issue in any of our repositories. If you need to reach us privately, please email hello@projectliberty.io.

node.title: DSNP in relation to Unfinished
node.excerpt:
Project Liberty began at an event in 2019 on Liberty Island, focused on a
question: Could we change technology to restore and then scale humanity’s
capacity to build trusted relationships, which are the bedrock of healthy
societies, economies, and democracies? We identified the possibility for just
such a model in what may seem an unexpected place: the concept at the core of
the social network itself, known as the social graph. The term "social graph"
isn't widely known beyond Internet technolog
node.plaintext:
Project Liberty began at an event in 2019 on Liberty Island, focused on a
question: Could we change technology to restore and then scale humanity’s
capacity to build trusted relationships, which are the bedrock of healthy
societies, economies, and democracies? We identified the possibility for just
such a model in what may seem an unexpected place: the concept at the core of
the social network itself, known as the social graph. The term "social graph"
isn't widely known beyond Internet technology circles, but it is a digital
representation of all the relationships between members of a social network.
When we use a social network—as nearly 60 percent of the world does—all the ways
we connect, learn, transact, consume, and contribute traverse this essential
online circuitry. The social graph holds immense power over us all, and the
largest social networks are owned and controlled by powerful, private companies,
each built on its own proprietary social graph. The key to change lies in the
power of combining our social networks in one unified social graph that is free
from corporate control and rewards innovators and value creators directly.

Late in 2019, Unfinished Labs [https://www.unfinishedlabs.io/] assembled a team
and began to build that social graph protocol. The Decentralized Social Network
Protocol (DSNP) is the result of their work, and DSNP.org is an independent
stewardship organization that serves as the home for ongoing development of the
DSNP specifications and open source code.

Opening the social graph for building is only the beginning. To enable a vibrant
ecosystem of apps that leverage the new social graph, Unfinished Labs continues
to develop essential tooling for rapid testing and launch of new social apps and
integration of social features into existing apps.
node.html:
Project Liberty began at an event in 2019 on Liberty Island, focused on a question: Could we change technology to restore and then scale humanity’s capacity to build trusted relationships, which are the bedrock of healthy societies, economies, and democracies? We identified the possibility for just such a model in what may seem an unexpected place: the concept at the core of the social network itself, known as the social graph. The term "social graph" isn't widely known beyond Internet technology circles, but it is a digital representation of all the relationships between members of a social network. When we use a social network—as nearly 60 percent of the world does—all the ways we connect, learn, transact, consume, and contribute traverse this essential online circuitry. The social graph holds immense power over us all, and the largest social networks are owned and controlled by powerful, private companies, each built on its own proprietary social graph. The key to change lies in the power of combining our social networks in one unified social graph that is free from corporate control and rewards innovators and value creators directly.

Late in 2019, Unfinished Labs assembled a team and began to build that social graph protocol. The Decentralized Social Network Protocol (DSNP) is the result of their work, and DSNP.org is an independent stewardship organization that serves as the home for ongoing development of the DSNP specifications and open source code.

Opening the social graph for building is only the beginning. To enable a vibrant ecosystem of apps that leverage the new social graph, Unfinished Labs continues to develop essential tooling for rapid testing and launch of new social apps and integration of social features into existing apps.

node.title: Mission & Activities
node.excerpt:
The mission of DSNP.org is to support community development of open source
technology and protocols to create a single, universally accessible, and
decentralized social graph.

Our primary activity is stable and responsible stewardship of the Decentralized
Social Network Protocol (DSNP). Because the protocol is available for anyone to
use, for both commercial and non-commercial purposes, our role is to help
implementors ensure the integrity and decentralized governance of the unified
and univers
node.plaintext:
The mission of DSNP.org is to support community development of open source
technology and protocols to create a single, universally accessible, and
decentralized social graph.

Our primary activity is stable and responsible stewardship of the Decentralized
Social Network Protocol (DSNP). Because the protocol is available for anyone to
use, for both commercial and non-commercial purposes, our role is to help
implementors ensure the integrity and decentralized governance of the unified
and universally accessible social graph. The integrity of the graph includes
DSNP's promises about people's privacy and control over their communications.
 To serve these goals:

 * We provide a framework for DSNP-related working groups and ongoing standards
   development (based loosely on the role of the IETF in Internet governance),
   and help participants interface with other standards bodies when needed.
 * We keep watch for unanticipated or adversarial centralization, and coordinate
   community response as needed. Decentralized systems usually have centralizing
   forces circulating within them, for example nodes that grow especially large
   and influential, and preserving true decentralization can sometimes require
   coordinated action.
 * We arrange virtual and in-person gatherings of DSNP implementors, both to
   help accelerate development and usage of DSNP as a technology and to ensure
   that there is a community of mutually familiar implementors who share a
   vision of DSNP's purpose.
 * We coordinate legal defense of DSNP if necessary (e.g., community patent
   defense).
 * We work transparently and in public as much as possible.  Anyone should be
   able to see what what DSNP.org is doing without necessarily being a
   participant.

Control of content flowing over DSNP is not within the scope of DSNP.org's
mission, and we do not take part in development of content filtering policy;
that is for nodes in and gateways to the graph to decide and implement.  Our
goal is maintenance of the protocol and the decentralized social graph in such a
way that the public interest is well-served by having individuals use DSNP-based
technologies to communicate.
node.html:
The mission of DSNP.org is to support community development of open source technology and protocols to create a single, universally accessible, and decentralized social graph.

Our primary activity is stable and responsible stewardship of the Decentralized Social Network Protocol (DSNP). Because the protocol is available for anyone to use, for both commercial and non-commercial purposes, our role is to help implementors ensure the integrity and decentralized governance of the unified and universally accessible social graph. The integrity of the graph includes DSNP's promises about people's privacy and control over their communications.  To serve these goals:

  • We provide a framework for DSNP-related working groups and ongoing standards development (based loosely on the role of the IETF in Internet governance), and help participants interface with other standards bodies when needed.
  • We keep watch for unanticipated or adversarial centralization, and coordinate community response as needed. Decentralized systems usually have centralizing forces circulating within them, for example nodes that grow especially large and influential, and preserving true decentralization can sometimes require coordinated action.
  • We arrange virtual and in-person gatherings of DSNP implementors, both to help accelerate development and usage of DSNP as a technology and to ensure that there is a community of mutually familiar implementors who share a vision of DSNP's purpose.
  • We coordinate legal defense of DSNP if necessary (e.g., community patent defense).
  • We work transparently and in public as much as possible.  Anyone should be able to see what what DSNP.org is doing without necessarily being a participant.

Control of content flowing over DSNP is not within the scope of DSNP.org's mission, and we do not take part in development of content filtering policy; that is for nodes in and gateways to the graph to decide and implement.  Our goal is maintenance of the protocol and the decentralized social graph in such a way that the public interest is well-served by having individuals use DSNP-based technologies to communicate.

node.title: Guiding Principles
node.excerpt:
We ground our work in a fairly simple ethos.  We've tried to lay them out here.
 This articulation might change over time, but our animating principles should
remain consistent.

 * Never build anything alone
 * Flexible beats prescient
 * Open wins from the bottom up

Our ethos echo the Bedrock Principles of the wider Unfinished ecosystem.  We
look forward to the Unfinished team rolling out those bedrocks into public view.
 For now, we'll just note that we align with their grounding in connecti
node.plaintext:
We ground our work in a fairly simple ethos.  We've tried to lay them out here.
 This articulation might change over time, but our animating principles should
remain consistent.

 * Never build anything alone
 * Flexible beats prescient
 * Open wins from the bottom up

Our ethos echo the Bedrock Principles of the wider Unfinished ecosystem.  We
look forward to the Unfinished team rolling out those bedrocks into public view.
 For now, we'll just note that we align with their grounding in connection,
vision, and collaboration.
node.html:
We ground our work in a fairly simple ethos.  We've tried to lay them out here.  This articulation might change over time, but our animating principles should remain consistent.

  • Never build anything alone
  • Flexible beats prescient
  • Open wins from the bottom up

Our ethos echo the Bedrock Principles of the wider Unfinished ecosystem.  We look forward to the Unfinished team rolling out those bedrocks into public view.  For now, we'll just note that we align with their grounding in connection, vision, and collaboration.

node.title: Governance
node.excerpt:
DSNP.org is governed by a Board of Directors, with the assistance of an Advisory
Council. To provide a stable base for early growth, the initial Board has a
majority representation from our founding partner, Unfinished, while also
including a significant number of independent directors. As the DSNP ecosystem
expands and matures, we will also be updating the process for selecting Board
members accordingly, with the expectation that Unfinished will become just one
constituent among many, so that t
node.plaintext:
DSNP.org is governed by a Board of Directors, with the assistance of an Advisory
Council. To provide a stable base for early growth, the initial Board has a
majority representation from our founding partner, Unfinished, while also
including a significant number of independent directors. As the DSNP ecosystem
expands and matures, we will also be updating the process for selecting Board
members accordingly, with the expectation that Unfinished will become just one
constituent among many, so that the Board represents the composition of the
entire DSNP ecosystem, as befits community-governed public infrastructure.

Why an entity?
DSNP.org is an independent entity to ensure that the community of people and
organizations that depend on the protocol have a place to convene, discuss
matters of common concern, and take collective action where appropriate.  One
such matter is the technical development of the protocol itself, of course:
establishing the standards that make DSNP-enabled applications mutually
compatible, and updating those standards to meet the community's functionality
needs in ways that align with DSNP's mission and values.  Another example is
addressing regulatory concerns, including helping regulators understand what
DSNP is and what it does.  These kinds of activities are best coordinated by an
independent entity that is able to foster discussion among a diverse group of
stakeholders without being beholden to any single stakeholder. DSNP.org also
needs to be able to adjust its governance to preserve this role in a changing
environment, which means it should not be subject to the governance constraints
of any other organization.
node.html:
DSNP.org is governed by a Board of Directors, with the assistance of an Advisory Council. To provide a stable base for early growth, the initial Board has a majority representation from our founding partner, Unfinished, while also including a significant number of independent directors. As the DSNP ecosystem expands and matures, we will also be updating the process for selecting Board members accordingly, with the expectation that Unfinished will become just one constituent among many, so that the Board represents the composition of the entire DSNP ecosystem, as befits community-governed public infrastructure.

Why an entity?

DSNP.org is an independent entity to ensure that the community of people and organizations that depend on the protocol have a place to convene, discuss matters of common concern, and take collective action where appropriate.  One such matter is the technical development of the protocol itself, of course: establishing the standards that make DSNP-enabled applications mutually compatible, and updating those standards to meet the community's functionality needs in ways that align with DSNP's mission and values.  Another example is addressing regulatory concerns, including helping regulators understand what DSNP is and what it does.  These kinds of activities are best coordinated by an independent entity that is able to foster discussion among a diverse group of stakeholders without being beholden to any single stakeholder. DSNP.org also needs to be able to adjust its governance to preserve this role in a changing environment, which means it should not be subject to the governance constraints of any other organization.

node.title: Karl Fogel
node.excerpt:
Karl Fogel has been an open source developer, author, project manager, and
specialist in collaborative development techniques since 1992.In 1995, he and
Jim Blandy co-founded Cyclic Software, the first company offering commercial
support for CVS, the free software version control system; in 1997 he added
support for anonymous read-only repository access to CVS. In 1999 he wrote Open
Source Development With CVS (Coriolis OpenPress). From 2000-2006, he worked for
CollabNet, Inc as a founding devel
node.plaintext:
Karl Fogel has been an open source developer, author, project manager, and
specialist in collaborative development techniques since 1992.In 1995, he and
Jim Blandy co-founded Cyclic Software, the first company offering commercial
support for CVS, the free software version control system; in 1997 he added
support for anonymous read-only repository access to CVS. In 1999 he wrote Open
Source Development With CVS (Coriolis OpenPress). From 2000-2006, he worked for
CollabNet, Inc as a founding developer in the Subversion project.
node.html: Karl Fogel has been an open source developer, author, project manager, and specialist in collaborative development techniques since 1992.In 1995, he and Jim Blandy co-founded Cyclic Software, the first company offering commercial support for CVS, the free software version control system; in 1997 he added support for anonymous read-only repository access to CVS. In 1999 he wrote Open Source Development With CVS (Coriolis OpenPress). From 2000-2006, he worked for CollabNet, Inc as a founding developer in the Subversion project.

node.title: Advisory Council Member 1
node.excerpt:
During the French and Indian War (known in Europe as the Seven Years War)
Washington won a reputation for bravery. He then returned to farming at Mount
Vernon, a plantation he had inherited from his half-brother. In 1759, he married
Martha Custis, a wealthy widow.
node.plaintext:
During the French and Indian War (known in Europe as the Seven Years War)
Washington won a reputation for bravery. He then returned to farming at Mount
Vernon, a plantation he had inherited from his half-brother. In 1759, he married
Martha Custis, a wealthy widow.
node.html: During the French and Indian War (known in Europe as the Seven Years War) Washington won a reputation for bravery. He then returned to farming at Mount Vernon, a plantation he had inherited from his half-brother. In 1759, he married Martha Custis, a wealthy widow.

node.excerpt:

flippant, insouciant personality. He is also characterized by a Brooklyn accent,
his portrayal as a trickster, and his catch phrase "Eh...What's up, doc?". Due
to Bugs' popularity during the golden age of American animation, he became not
only an American cultural icon and the official mascot of Warner Bros.
Entertainment, but also one of the most recognizable characters in the world. He
can thus be seen in the older
node.plaintext:
Bugs is an anthropomorphic gray and white rabbit or hare who is famous for his
flippant, insouciant personality. He is also characterized by a Brooklyn accent,
his portrayal as a trickster, and his catch phrase "Eh...What's up, doc?". Due
to Bugs' popularity during the golden age of American animation, he became not
only an American cultural icon and the official mascot of Warner Bros.
Entertainment, but also one of the most recognizable characters in the world. He
can thus be seen in the older Warner Bros. company logos.
node.html: Bugs is an anthropomorphic gray and white rabbit or hare who is famous for his flippant, insouciant personality. He is also characterized by a Brooklyn accent, his portrayal as a trickster, and his catch phrase "Eh...What's up, doc?". Due to Bugs' popularity during the golden age of American animation, he became not only an American cultural icon and the official mascot of Warner Bros. Entertainment, but also one of the most recognizable characters in the world. He can thus be seen in the older Warner Bros. company logos.

node.title: James Vasile
node.excerpt:
James Vasile [https://startpage.com/?query=james%20vasile] has fifteen years
experience as a user, developer, advocate and advisor in the free and open
source software world. His expertise is in software licensing and
community-building, as well as non-profit and small business startup. He focuses
on free software and open source production, although his work and interests
often take him far beyond the world of software. Much of what James does
involves teaching people how to build successful bu
node.plaintext:
James Vasile [https://startpage.com/?query=james%20vasile] has fifteen years
experience as a user, developer, advocate and advisor in the free and open
source software world. His expertise is in software licensing and
community-building, as well as non-profit and small business startup. He focuses
on free software and open source production, although his work and interests
often take him far beyond the world of software. Much of what James does
involves teaching people how to build successful businesses around free software
and ensuring licensing alignment in multisource FOSS stacks.  James's technical
experience also allows him to act as outsource CTO/Architect, due-diligence open
source expert, new venture advisor, fiscal sponsorship facilitator, and more.
node.html: James Vasile has fifteen years experience as a user, developer, advocate and advisor in the free and open source software world. His expertise is in software licensing and community-building, as well as non-profit and small business startup. He focuses on free software and open source production, although his work and interests often take him far beyond the world of software. Much of what James does involves teaching people how to build successful businesses around free software and ensuring licensing alignment in multisource FOSS stacks.  James's technical experience also allows him to act as outsource CTO/Architect, due-diligence open source expert, new venture advisor, fiscal sponsorship facilitator, and more.
